dict.string: In Episode 112, Trev and AJ “get macro with it” while doing a quick catch up, and respond to a few listener questions about audition meeting conflict sheets and “made for reel” reel footage before sitting down for the third and final part of their chat with actor/filmmaker Blake Robbins and actor/director Armin Shimerman.

In Episode 111, Trev and AJ discuss the legitimacy of dumpster diving and Craigslist flipping, weigh the dangers and possibilities of “cross-branding” yourself via thrival jobs, and what it could mean to GO ALL IN. Then Trev sits down for Part 2 of a 3-part chat with returning guest Blake Robbins – to chat about the nuts and bolts of making a feature film – and Armin Shimerman (Deep Space 9).

In Episode 110, Trev and AJ recap their weeks, talk about playing big, “being ready so you don’t have to get ready”, and one thing that just about all casting directors want to see on your resumé. Then Trev sits down for Part 1 of a 3-part chat with returning guest Blake Robbins – to chat about the nuts-and-bolts of making a feature film – and Armin Shimerman (Deep Space 9).

In Episode 109, Trev and AJ recap their (fairly chill) weeks, the one simple way to build bulletproof relationships, how gratitude is it’s own reward, and why IAP is no longer on Stitcher. Then they sit down for with actor/musician/professional organizer Fay Wolf for the second half of their chat on the artist’s journey.

In Episode 108, Trev and AJ share what’s new, respond to a few listener questions, then sit down with actor/musician/professional organizer Fay Wolf for the first part of an unexpectedly profound chat on the artist’s journey.

In Episode 107 of Inside Acting, Trev & AJ honor a fallen comrade, catch up on their goings on, and respond to a fantastic “thrival” job listener question before sitting down for Part 2 of their chat with Quddus Philippe – a guy who went from no-name radio DJ in Canada to male model to host of TRL and Duets to producer of web and TV. And he’s just getting started.

In Episode 106, Trev and AJ do a decidedly epic catch up, respond to some fantastic listener questions, and sit down with host/producer Quddus Philippe for Part 1 of their chat about how he went from a no-name radio VJ in Canada to male model, host of TRL and Duets, and now producer of web and TV – with more exciting philanthropic and entertainment projects on the horizon.

In Episode 105, Trev and AJ sit down with veteran actor Larry Cedar (Deadwood, National Treasure, Pinky and the Brain) for the second half of their chat on his journey – and the philosophy behind this acting thing we do.

In Episode 104, Trev and AJ chat about AJ’s recent meeting, Trev’s Mindmovie and P90X Ultimate Comeback Challenge, and the podcast’s new technical producer, actor/filmmaker César Gamiño. Then they sit down with veteran actor Larry Cedar (Deadwood, National Treasure, Pinky and the Brain) for the first of a two-part chat on his journey – and the philosophy behind his acting thing we do.

In Episode 103, Trev and AJ chat about work begetting work and continue the discussion about the issue – or non-issue – of sexuality in scenes, projects, and the industry in general. Then Trev sits down for the third and final part of his chat with actor/producer Ace Marrero about the journey from no-name Jersey Kid to star and producer of feature films.

In Episode 102, Trev and AJ catch each other up on their weeks, talk “brand-modification” and leadership, and respond to a listener question about… L.A. traffic. Then Trev sits down with actor/producer Ace Marrero for Part 2 of their chat about his journey from no-name Jersey Kid to star and producer of feature films.

Episode 100! Trev and AJ join an expert panel of SAG-AFTRA board, committee, and staff members, in addition to a representative from the SAG Foundation, to chat about their unique perspectives on national and local issues, answer questions, and educate the audience on how the union will be moving forward post-merger.

Panel includes Ray Bradford (National Director of Policy and Diversity Advocacy), Ilyanne Morden Kichaven (Executive Director, Los Angeles), Jill Seltzer (Executive Director, SAG Foundation), Woody Schultz (Chair, National Performance Capture Committee), Ned Vaughn (Executive Vice President, SAG-AFTRA National Board).
With Episode 100 upon us, Trev and AJ take some time to reflect on the journey to triple digits — thanks in large part to a listener e-mail. Keep an ear out for the discounts and announcements!

In Episode 098, Trev and AJ give a quick recap of their week, share a listener’s experience with casting director workshops (especially as they pertain to last week’s interview), and then sit down with casting director / writer / director / musician Billy DaMota for the final part of their chat on actors, workshops, and DIYing.

Trev & AJ kick off Episode 097 with some announcements, and a recap of (yet another) one of AJ’s pilot meetings — and the Jedi-like mindset that’s getting him results. Then they share their thoughts on starting an IAP-like podcast, share some listener feedback about the Seattle market, respond to a listener question about the role age plays in a budding career, and then finally chat about being pigeonholed by peers and co-workers… or is it us who pigeonhole ourselves?

Then they sit down with casting director Billy DaMota for Part 1 of their chat on paying for casting director workshops. Warning: this may change the way you view pay-to-play CD meetings.

In Episode 096, Trev and AJ discuss their big learns for the week and respond to a “dissenting” listener voicemail before sitting down with actor and Actor’s Network founder Kevin E. West for Part 2 of their chat on what it takes to exist as an actor in Los Angeles.

In Episode 095, Trev and AJ catch up on the skillz, tools, and ways of being they’re picking up via the work they’re doing, as well offer their thoughts on two listener questions - about moving *away* from L.A., and a continuation of how and where sexuality plays a role in an acting career.

In Episode 094, AJ and Trev both share some great (individual) news before responding to two listeners questions about finding thrival work in L.A., and how much of a role sexuality plays in casting and the industry. Then they sit down for the third and final part of their massively insightful conversation with actor/filmmaker Blake Robbins.

In Episode 093, Trev and AJ talk P90X, how AJ “paradigm shifts” his to-do list, and propose an Inside Acting Fitness Challenge Group (are you in?!). Then they respond to two listener questions on union status, reels, and scoring representation - that almost seem to be made for each other - before sitting down for Part 2 of their 3-part chat with prolific actor/filmmaker (Flash Forward, The Office, Oz) Blake Robbins. Listen for the kickass announcement at the end!

Happy 2013! In Episode 092, Trev and AJ have a quick catch up before responding to a few listener questions about day jobs and competition vs paying it forward, then jump into Part 1 of a not-to-be-missed chat with actor/writer/filmmaker Blake Robbins.
In Episode 091, Trev flies short and sweet to make way for a full size interview with cinematographer/editor/producer Miguel Amodio.
In Episode 090, Trev and AJ sit down with actor-turned-producer and life/career coach Ryan Basham for an epic hour-plus of inspiration and motivation.

In Episode 089, AJ recaps his experience on the set of Broken Horses and Trev shares some (more!) great news about his short film Donor. Then they wax philosophical on what it is to “create an experience” as an actor and AJ responds to a listener voicemail about some of the ins and outs of equity theatre before Trev sits down for the second of his 2-part nuts-and-bolts chat with actor Jen Lilley (General Hospital).

In Episode 088, Trev and AJ chat about the goods and evils of actors vs. credit cards, recap AJ’s first day of shooting, and respond to listener questions about accents and the unions. Then Trev sits down for Part 1 of a 2-part chat with working actor Jen Lilley (General Hospital).

In Episode 087, Trev and AJ continue to talk MITT (sorry everyone) and do the weekly catch up — in which AJ shares some majorly awesome news. Then they sit down for the final piece of their 3-part chat with New York Times bestselling writer Matt Logelin about what it’s like to have his (heartbreaking and) personal story turned into a Lifetime movie.

In Episode 086, Trev and AJ recap their weeks, chatting about repeat business, AJ’s last-minute cramming session for an understudy role at Boston Court, and more about the why’s and why nots behind — le sigh — casting director workshops. Then the two sit down with New York Times bestselling writer Matt Logelin for the second of a 3-part conversation about what it’s like to have his (heartbreaking and) personal story turned into a Lifetime movie.

In Episode 085, Trev and AJ chat about the indie feature film they’re shooting — PRODIGAL SON — sticking to their guns once they’ve set their intention, and how to (*if* to) publicize projects that, well, might kinda suck a little bit.

Then they sit down with New York Times best-selling writer Matt Logelin for Part 1 of a 3-part conversation about what it’s like to have his personal story turned into a Lifetime movie.

In Episode 084, Trev and AJ recap talk more MITT (it’s just been that great for them) and respond to a few listener questions before sitting down for the third and final part of their chat with actor Woody Schultz (Avatar, Beowulf, The Polar Express, How I Met Your Mother) to wrap up their talk on motion capture (”mocap”), voiceover, the unions, and why Woody hasn’t had the need for a thrival job in 10+ years. How about them apples?

In Episode 083, Trev flies solo, keeping it short and… well, just short before he and AJ sit down for Part 2 of their 3-part chat with actor Woody Schultz (Avatar, Beowulf, The Polar Express, How I Met Your Mother) for an insider’s look at the unions — what they do, what they stand for, why they rock, and how to get involved — before digging into his experience as a motion capture (”mocap”) actor.

In Episode 082: Trev shares some more cool news about his short film Donor while AJ preps for his first *official* VO audition meeting. Then the two of them respond to a listener voicemail before sitting down with actor actor Woody Schultz (Avatar, Beowulf, The Polar Express, How I Met Your Mother) — the true “guy behind the guy” — to chat about his journey from actor to production assistant… and back to actor again in Part 1 of an epic 3-parter on self-educating, building careers that last, when and why you should join the unions, and what it’s like working in motion capture (”mocap”).

In Episode 081, Trev and AJ chat about AJ’s budding computer consultation startup, and Trev’s first face-to-face encounter with M.I.T.T. — and (spoiler alert) the rabbit hole goes kinda deep. Then they sit down with Mad Men actor Darren Pettie for the second part of their chat about his unlikely journey to Hollywood, and how he keeps on keeping on.

In Episode 080, Trev and AJ chat about the power of saying no (so long as it’s not coming from a place ego — and is aligned with the larger vision for your life), as well the one thing that instantly takes you from amateur to pro status: shipping. Then they sit down with Mad Men actor Darren Pettie for Part 1 of a 2-part chat about his unlikely journey to Hollywood.

In Episode 079, Trev and AJ dissect the delicate (and powerful!) art of ‘leveling up’ in an acting career — and all the armchair psychology that entails — before sitting down for Part 2 of their fantastic chat with actor/producer/marketing specialist Emily Grace.

In Episode 078, Trev and AJ recap AJ’s recent gig in Australia and Trev’s recent non-gig in Vermont. Then Trev sits down with actor/producer/marketing specialist Emily Grace for part 1 of a great 2-part chat on defining and marketing an acting career.
Trev flies solo in Episode 077, keeping it short and sweet before he and AJ sit down for Part 2 of their chat with filmmaker Ryan Sage.

Trev and AJ chat about the crucial-ness of staying in (artistic) shape, the crucial-ness of having a second, sustainable, and enjoyable source of income, and why committed action is better than coffee. Then they sit down with filmmaker Ryan Sage  for Part 1 of their chat about unconventional ways to make kickass films on a budget — and how Ryan’s first feature, “A Big Love Story” (formerly “Worth the Weight”) all started with a CraigsList ad.

In Episode 075, Trev and AJ dish about confidence, ease, authenticity, and other actor essential in-the-room intangibles, respond to a listener voicemail about minor markets (thanks for the call Erica!), and then sit down with Colleen “The Communicatrix” Wainwright for Part 2 of a fantastic conversation the possibilities and pitfalls of marketing, relationship building, and - of course - communicating.

In Episode 74 Trev flies solo, giving a brief audio tour of the newly-tweaked Inside Acting website and sharing a few details of what’s in the works before sitting down for Part 1 of his chat with Colleen “The Communicatrix” Waingwright.

In Episode 074 Trev flies solo, giving a brief audio tour of the newly-tweaked Inside Acting website and sharing a few details of what’s in the works before sitting down for Part 1 of his chat withColleen “The Communicatrix” Wainwright.

In Episode 73, Trev and AJ do their weekly catch up and share a few lessons learned before going deeper down the rabbit hole with acting coach/filmmaker Anthony Meindl for Part 2 of their noodle-baking interview.

In Episode 72, Trev and AJ recap their weeks and wax a little woo-woo on the Nature of The Universe and the only way to conquer fear. Then they sit down with the man himself, Anthony Meindl, for Part 1 a fantastic chat on, well, the non-acting of good acting.
In Episode 71, Trev and AJ do a much needed catch up before sitting down with professional-painter-turned-professional-screenwriter Steve Allrich.

In Episode 70 of Inside Acting, AJ recaps his Nor Cal adventures with Of Mice and Men before Trev sits down with actor / producer / fitness enthusiast Cuyle Carvin for Part 2 of his chat on eating smart and how he’s built his career so far.

In Episode 69, Trev sits down with actor / producer / fitness enthusiast Cuyle Carvin to chat about his journey from New York to Los Angeles, how he turns “fan messages” (our words, not his) into acting roles and producing gigs, and the power of just saying yes.

In Episode 68, Trev and AJ give this whole new fangled video thing another go for an entire episode, chatting about their “learns” for the week, and sitting down with actor and Starcraft/Ancient Aliens voiceover star Robert Clotworthy for Part 2 of his interview on how he’s gotten from Point A to Point B.

In Episode 67, Trev and AJ recap the reasons behind the long-ass wait between episodes, AJ relates some great - really great - news, and Trev gets a little sappy (or honest, depending on how you look at it) with how he’s been feeling these past few weeks. Then they respond to a few listener questions before sitting down with Vampire Mob writer/director/creator Joe Wilson on his journey and how he’s created his own cult following.

Happy New Year! In Episode 66, Trev and AJ share some success e-mails from listeners, talk about the unexpected awesomeness of a) taking a break, and b) The Artist’s Way, recap a few “scammy actor e-mails” they’ve recently received, and touch on the highly subjective topic of when (or when not) to do extra work. Then they sit down with the incomparable Emily Rose to continue their conversation about her audition process, relocating for Haven, and doing motion capture work for the Uncharted games.

In Episode 65, Trev and AJ recap their last few auditions (erm, meetings!), give their thoughts on self-taping reads, and respond to a listener voicemail. Then AJ sits down with actor/voiceover artist Robert Clotworthy (Ancient Aliens, StarCraft) for Part 1 of a great 2-part interview.

In Episode 64, AJ teams up with Ben Whitehair (filling in for Trev) as they chat about actor websites, marketing yourself as an actor, and what’s been keeping them busy. Then Trev & AJ continue their kickass chat with actor Emily Rose in Part 2 of their interview.

In Episode 63, Trev and AJ ruminate on the “holiday dip” and wax a little GTD on Trev’s new goal: read 52 Books in 52 Weeks. Then they sit down for the first part of what just might be their favorite interview to date — star of the Uncharted games and Syfy series Haven, actress Emily Rose.

In Episode 62, Trev & AJ chat about getting back on the horse after a big production, what’s been keeping them busy, and wonder how to stay afloat - spiritually-speaking - when the going gets tough and there’s no end in sight. Then Trev sits down for Part 2 of his kickass chat with writer/director/producer Bernie Su.

In Episode 61, Trev and AJ recap their experience with Gospel According to First Squad, give a huge shout out to all the IAP listeners who came (and all the listeners who help support the podcast financially), ruminate on what may or may not be next, and talk about recent auditions - eh-hem, *meetings* - and bookings. Then Trev sits down for Part 1 of his chat with webfrontiersman and all-around brilliant guy Bernie Su for an insider’s look at business-ifying your content creation.

In Episode 60, Trev and AJ share what’s been keeping them (a little too) busy, AJ recounts the latest chapter in his “ongoing representation saga” (and indulges in his first official industry rant), and both offer their thoughts on some listener questions — when they feel the “right” time to take a meeting is, and what software options and books are out there to help you write a killer (and properly formatted) script. Then Trev and AJ sit down for Part 2 of their kickass interview with the inimitable “web-frontiersman” — a literary invention of AJ’s that’s apparently sticking — Yuri Baranovsky to chat about the future of entertainment and the web, and how he makes a living with his production company, Happy Little Guillotine Films.

In Episode 59, Trev and AJ chat about dealing with distractions while onstage and share their thoughts on actor websites and how/when/why to turn or not turn down roles and projects before sitting down for Part 1 of a 2-part interview with writer/actor/director/producer/”webfrontiersman” (AJ’s word) Yuri Baranovsky.

Trev and AJ overcome Mercury’s Retrograde to bring you Episode 58 of Inside Acting, where they talk more about actors and LinkedIn, funding your Kickstarter campaign, and filmmakers skirting studios to go direct to their audiences. Then AJ sits down with writer/producer/composer Ron Rappaport for one of his favorite chats yet.

In Episode 57, AJ and Trev do a quick recap of what’s been keeping them busy, and continue to kick around their thoughts on independent theatre and some of the unique challenges actors face in self-promotion before AJ hits up the most recent L.A. Actor’s TweetUp to talk to… well, YOU GUYS!
In Episode 56, Trev and AJ wax philosophical on the current state of theatre, respond to some listener questions and comments, and sit down for Part 2 of their chat with ultra-hyphenate Rick Zieff.

In Episode 55, AJ and Trev catch up on their recent meetings and projects, wax a little administrative on union memberships, and talk about workarounds for performing and/or shooting copyrighted work before sitting down with ultra-hyphenate Rick Zieff to talk the ins and outs of voiceover.

In Episode 54, AJ talks about the biggest audition of his career, while Trev talks about shooting his first short film script with a bunch of amazing (like really amazing) people. Then they weigh the pros and cons of e-mailing casting directors and linking your LinkedIn account with, you know, your career before AJ sits down with screenwriter and indie film producer Tim Morell.

In Episode 53, Trev and AJ chat about the 2011 Pilot Report and undergrad vs grad vs nothing at all before Trev sits down with writer Kit Steinkellner for the second of a two-part interview on creating your own work (well, the writing part, at least).

In Episode 52, AJ joins forces with co-producer Nelson Murray and correspondent Melissa Collins to cover the 2011 ShowBiz Expo in downtown L.A. Get the inside scoop on who was there, what was awesome, what sucked, and why.

In Episode 51 of Inside Acting, Trev and AJ catch up on what’s been keeping them busy (or not busy), chat about mindset, coping with industry lulls, and how to market your projects to agents and casting directors. Then Trev sits down with playwright and screenwriter Kit Steinkellner for the first of two inside acting conversations on writing.

In Episode 50, Trev and AJ celebrate the 50th episode of Inside Acting (!!!), share two exciting announcements (listen close for the IAP-exclusive discount), and talk about how and when to interview representation before Trev sits down for Part 2 of his chat with working British actors TJ Ramini and Aml Ameen (listen close for the second IAP-exclusive discount!).
Episode 049: TJ Ramini & Aml Ameen (Part 1 of 2)

In Episode 49, Trev and AJ chat about what’s been keeping them busy, how to cure “aloof” agents, and share their experiences getting a theatre company off the ground before sitting down with actors TJ Ramini and Aml Ameen to talk, well, acting.
In Episode 48, AJ sits down with actor and tax specialist Micah Scott for an in-depth conversation on the ins and outs of actor taxes.

In Episode 47, Trev and AJ recap their weeks of “meetings,” wax philosophical on the audition process, and respond to a listener voicemail about why plays largely aren’t available as eBooks. Then Trev sits down for the second and final part of a majorly kickass interview with Abundance Bound founder and actress, writer, and personal finance guru Miata Edoga.

In Episode 46, Trev and AJ talk about the always semi-awkward experience of watching yourself onscreen, recap their experience at the most recent L.A. Actor’s TweetUp, follow a listener question down the rabbit hole of “dominant realities” and the x-factor, and talk tea. Then Trev sits down with actor/writer/personal finance guru Miata Edoga for Part 1 of a 2-part interview about “going pro” with your finances.

In Episode 45, Trev and AJ follow up on last episode’s “horror stories,” catch up on each other’s happenings, and respond to a few listener questions before Trev sits down with actor/writer/musician/photographer - and ‘Group: The Musical’ creator - Adam Emperor-Southard to wax poetic on the creative process.

In Episode 44, Trev and AJ talk about “off” auditions, continue the great age debate, and give their thoughts on reel material before launching into a collection of listener-submitted “audition horror stories.” Some are funny, some are scary, some are… well, just unique.

In Episode 43, Trev and AJ chat about the importance (or non-importance) of disclosing your age, “location-based goals” for your career, and their thoughts on class and grad school. Then they sit down with actor/writer/director/producer Marianna Palka to talk about her feature film, starting and running a production company, and, well, just being cool.

In Episode 42, Trev and AJ talk about what’s been keeping them busy and respond to some listener e-mails and voicemails before jumping into Part 2 of their 2-part chat with casting director Marci Liroff.

Happy New Year! In Episode 41, Trev and AJ talk about what’s been keeping them busy, how they handle “rejection,” discuss dialect resources, and wax philosophical on “the actor’s responsibility” before diving into Part 1 of 2-part conversation with casting director Marci Liroff.

In Episode 40 (the final IAP of 2010), Trev & AJ recap their recent “meeting” experiences and their individual 2010’s before sitting down for Part 2 of their nuts-and-bolts, let-me-break-it-down-for-you interview with actor Mark Atteberry. Lots of great stuff here from Mark - learn it, live it, love it!

In Episode 39, Trev and AJ chat about Group (Trev’s new musical WHAT), writing, and, well, “just doing the work” before sitting down for Part 1 of a majorly kickass nuts-and-bolts interview with actor Mark Atteberry. Seriously, don’t miss it - this guy is awesome.

In Episode 38, Trev and AJ chat about the “tea lifestyle,” what’s been keeping them busy, and different ways to get a copy of your project footage before sitting down with actor/teacher Bjorn Johnson for Part 2 of their insightful interview on career.

In Episode 37, Trev and AJ chat about what’s been keeping them busy, the learning process, and redefining the word “audition” before sitting down with actor/teacher Bjorn Johnson to talk 99-seat theatre, acting class, the importance of developing yourself, and balancing your thrival job with your career. Part 1 of a 2-part interview.

In Episode 36, Trev & AJ hit Backstage’s annual Actorfest, podcasting “live” from the California Market Center and offering their thoughts on the services, guests, panels, seminars, workshops, and on the event as a whole.

In Episode 35, “TrAJ” chat about what’s been keeping them busy and respond to two very honest and candid voicemails before sitting down with actor/writer/producer Taryn O’Neill for Part 2 of an inspiring interview on creating your own work.

In Episode 34, Trev and AJ talk about their experiences on set, uncomfortable audition situations, respond to a few listener questions, and talk about what success means to them before sitting down for Part 1 of a 2-part interview with self-made actor/producer Taryn O’Neill.

In Episode 33, Trev and AJ respond to a few listener questions and chat about the importance (or lack thereof) of youth and beauty in Hollywood, the efficiency of doing drop-offs, and give their take on the online acting class thing before sitting down for Part 2 of their interview with working actor James Leo Ryan.

In Episode 32, Trev & AJ chat about readjusting to life after gigs and bring back the “Pick of the Week” before Trev sits down to chat with actor James Leo Ryan for Part 1 of their conversation about type, specificity, and working as a guest star.
In Episode 31, Trev and AJ chat about web video, “tone,” and preparing for a job before sitting down for Part 2 of their interview with Beverly Hills Playhouse Executive Director Allen Barton.

In Episode 30, Trev & AJ talk ethnicity in Hollywood, share their thoughts on reality TV, then sit down with the Beverly Hills Playhouse Executive Director Allen Barton for Part 1 of a two-part noodle-baking interview.

In Episode 29, Trev & AJ chat about the big wide world of technique, shamelessly plug The War Cycle, and sit down for Part 2 of their interview with actor/writer/director/producer — and co-creator/star of the award-winning webseries (and now feature-length film) The Bannen Way — Mark Gantt.

In Episode 28, Trev and AJ talk about what’s been keeping them (very) busy, respond to a great listener voicemail, and talk about the casting process before jumping into Part 1 of a majorly kickass interview with actor/writer/director/producer — and co-creator of the award-winning webseries (and now feature-length film) The Bannen Way — Mark Gantt.

Back from a month-long hiatus, Trev and AJ join forces with blogger and actor-preneur Ben Whitehair for a special episode about the all-elusive actor “thrival” job. Join us as we knock through a few dozen listener-submitted alternative ideas for alternative income streams, all discussed, submitted, and — in many cases — created by actors.

In Episode 26, Trev and AJ chat about knowing when you’re ready, redefining failure, and rejecting rejection before sitting down with actor J.K. Simmons (Juno, Spider Man, The Closer) for Part 2 of their discussion on fallback plans (or lack thereof), career longevity, and why “the play’s the thing.”

Trev and AJ Skype it in for Episode 25, and discuss a few listener questions before sitting down with actor J.K. Simmons (Spider Man, Juno, Oz, The Closer) for the first of a two-part, knowledge bomb-filled interview.

In Episode 24, Trev and AJ sit down with casting director Bonnie Gillespie for one of their best discussion on the casting process — and the whole CD workshop “thing” — yet. Get ready to feel empowered.

In Episode 23, Trev and AJ respond to a few more listener questions and chat about voiceover resources, “subjective” dialects, the almighty Actor Day Job, and the financial struggles that we often face as actors. Then they sit down with commercial casting director Laurie Records for the second half of a great conversation about the business of commercials.

In Episode 22, Trev and AJ talk New York vs L.A., discuss (actually sort of argue over) resumé and headshot do’s and dont’s, get a little new-man-sensitive about the renegade lifestyle that actors choose, and then sit down for Part 1 of a knowledge bomb-filled chat with commercial casting director Laurie Records.

In Episode 21, Trev and AJ talk about Trev’s new side business, musicians “versus” actors, and putting your life on hold to jump into one project immediately following another, last minute style, dialects and multiple characters and all. Then Trev sits down with Chico’s Angels masterminds Oscar Quintero and Kurt Koehler to talk about creating your own work and the value of playing to stereotype in comedy.

In Episode 20, Trev and AJ talk about the “alternative” (but not uncommon) world of agency representation, feeling the pressure to book, and the things you CAN control in your career. Check out the IAP website for a text-only PDF download of this episode’s fantastic interview — A Conversation with The Working Actress.
In Episode 19, Trev and AJ pimp some of their favorite resource blogs while Trev sits down for Part 2 of an inspiring chat with actor and award-winning DIY indie filmmaker Tony Rago.

In Episode 18, Trev and AJ catch up on their shows, while Trev talks a bit more about dealing with some burnout and AJ relates an insightful story about his agent courtings. Then IAP correspondent Melissa Collins sits down with ‘The Wake’ actors Heidi Schreck and Emily Donahoe to talk shop about pro theatre, odd day jobs, and the many lives of a the working actor.
In Episode 17, Trev flies solo and sits down for Part 1 of an exciting conversation with actor and award-winning indie filmmaker Tony Rago.

In Episode 16, Trev and AJ do a goal check-in, discuss actors as “products”, dish on cold reading techniques, and continue an inspiring and insightful conversation (Part 2 of 2) with Steven Spielberg’s go-to guy, actor Neal McDonough. And be sure to listen closely for AJ’s (quite literal) knowledge bomb

In Episode 15, Trev and Albert field a few listener voicemails and discuss stage names, IMDB Pro, and the “developing actor”, then sit down for Part 1 of an insightful and inspiring interview with Steven Spielberg’s go-to guy, actor Neal McDonough.

In Episode 14, Trev and Albert catch up on what’s been keeping them busy, respond to a few listener voicemails, talk about their favorite acting books, and sit down for Part 1 of a fantastic interview with casting director Bonnie Gillespie.
